awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Ergodic Control of Stochastic Differential Equations Driven By a Class of Pure-Jump Levy Processes, and Applications to Stochastic Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Queueing processes in large-scale networks are ubiquitous in society as exemplified by patient flow in hospitals, telephone call centers, service networks, and manufacturing and service operations management. This research will provide fundamental theoretical understanding of these queueing processes in the presence of batch arrivals. The results of this research will be put into direct applications to real-world stochastic networks through collaborations with the health systems and system analysis industry. This research will support under-represented minority groups and train young STEM graduates with new mathematical skills.
  
This research concerns ergodic control problems for systems described by Ito stochastic differential equations (SDEs) driven by pure-jump Levy processes. The research objectives are: (1) to develop a comprehensive theoretical framework for ergodic control for a large class of controlled SDEs driven by a pure-jump Levy process; (2) to study a novel fully nonlinear problem that arises in admission control and falls outside the usual paradigm of stochastic control; and (3) to develop value iteration algorithms and spatial approximation methods in order to study large time asymptotics, and also to facilitate the numerical solution of the associated Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equations, and the design of learning schemes for adaptive control in the presence of unknown parameters. This research will advance the basic science of applied mathematics and stochastic control, and make fundamental contributions to applied probability and stochastic networks.

por.por_cntn:
This research has studied ergodic control problems for systems described by Ito stochastic differential equations (SDEs) driven by pure-jump Levy processes. These models arise as limits of the queueing processes of parallel server stochastic networks with bursty arrivals and/or in an alternating renewal random environment, and can be used in a variety of application contexts in large-scale data centers, telecommunications, manufacturing and service systems. This research has advanced the basic science of applied mathematics and stochastic control, and make fundamental contributions to applied probability and stochastic networks. The results have a broad impact on real-world applications, providing skills and tools to guide the design and management of complex stochastic systems. This research has trained young STEM graduates with new mathematical skills. 

This research has produced ground-breaking methodologies and transformative techniques to study ergodic control problems for a broad class of SDEs with jumps which includes those arising in the study of stochastic networks and queueing systems in heavy traffic. The analytical tools developed have solved important open control problems for these models.  The PIs have been successful in extending ergodic control theory to models satisfying much weaker structural assumptions. At the same time, the PIs have made fundamental contributions to the theory of non-local partial differential equations, which forms the analytical framework of SDEs with jumps. New Lyapunov methods are developed to establish the uniform stability properties of the multiclass networks under all stationary Markov scheduling policies. Novel adaptive control algorithms are developed to facilitate the numerical solutions of the associated optimality equations.
